title: Utter shamble : Man City fans stuck in 50 MINUTE queue to get out of car park after sell out women match
body_text:
'Utter shambles': Man City fans stuck in 50 MINUTE queue to get out of car park after sell out women's match
The club has since apologised and said they were 'disappointed' by the 'extended wait times'
Football fans claimed they were stuck for 50 minutes trying to get out of a car park after the Manchester City women's game on Sunday (October 8).
Following the sell-out match, between Man City and Chelsea at the Joie Stadium, huge queues of cars were seen lining up as drivers tried to get out of the Blue Car Park, beside the stadium.
One fan, Paul Clarke, said he was stuck for '50 minutes' and that the delays were made worse as scores of cars had to filter into one lane to exit at the junction with Alan Turing Way.

The club has since apologised and said they were 'disappointed' by the 'extended wait times'. They added that the situation was mainly caused by a lane closure on site and roadworks taking place nearby and that they have undertaken an 'in depth review' on their parking operation to make improvements going forward.
Paul, who shared pictures of queues of cars waiting to exit the car park on Sunday, said: "It was a sell out crowd for the women's game. There was one lane open out of a packed free blue car park.
"There were people in long queues filtering into the one lane. The game had finished well over an hour ago. There was no-one obvious from the club controlling traffic flow. Utter shambles.
"It appears main exit road was shut as heavy machinery was on it, so cars were leaving though one gate near the main road, where there are also traffic lights."
He claimed 'hundreds' were stuck in the large car park and shared a number of pictures to social media showing the extent of the queues.
A spokesperson for Manchester City said: “We are committed to creating the best possible matchday experience for our fans, meaning we are disappointed by the extended wait times when leaving yesterday’s sell-out match and we wish to apologise to all those impacted.
"The situation was largely caused by a lane closure on site, further impacted by a signalling issue and roadworks taking place on several surrounding roads.
"To reduce wait times in the future, we have undertaken an in-depth review of our free parking operation with internal and external stakeholders and have identified a series of measures to improve the flow of cars which we will introduce ahead of this week’s match.”
